description:
Cephus cinctus, commonly known as the wheat stem sawfly, is a species of insect belonging to the order Hymenoptera and the family Cephidae. This pest is primarily found in the northern Great Plains region of North America, where it is considered a significant agricultural concern due to its ability to damage wheat crops.

The wheat stem sawfly is a small, slender insect with a black body and yellow markings. It measures approximately 6-10 millimeters in length and has a distinctive saw-like ovipositor that is used to lay eggs inside the stems of wheat plants. The larvae that hatch from these eggs feed on the internal tissues of the plant, weakening the stem and making it susceptible to lodging (the bending or breaking of the stem).

The life cycle of the wheat stem sawfly begins in the spring, when the adult females emerge and lay their eggs within the wheat stems. The larvae then undergo several molts before pupating within the stem. In the fall, the mature larvae exit the stem and burrow into the soil, where they overwinter and emerge as adults the following spring.

The wheat stem sawfly is considered a significant pest due to its ability to reduce wheat yields and affect the quality of the grain. Effective management strategies involve the use of resistant wheat cultivars, cultural practices such as delayed planting, and the application of insecticides when necessary.
